For instance, with the nationwide implementation of mass testing in all municipalities, we might witness a more rapid decline in infection rates than anticipated based on the municipal-level data alone. This accelerated decrease could be an emergent property arising from a variety of factors such as increased collective responsibility, (inter)national media attention, more efficient resource allocation, or enhanced data for tracking and managing the spread of the virus. These factors, invisible at a more constrained municipal level observation, come to the fore and exert significant influence when the scope is expanded. This is an example of how macro-scale patterns, which feed back to affect the micro-scale dynamics, can emerge when we increase our scope.

Emergence and interconnectedness are inexorably linked. Consider water, which can exist in different states, such as ice and steam, and carbon monoxide, a gas with entirely different components. Although ice and steam share the same components (i.e., water molecules), they appear very different due to the differential connections between the molecules -whereas carbon monoxide, a completely different substance, appears very similar to steam. This is because molecules in steam and carbon monoxide move independently, whereas those molecules of ice are bound together. This example demonstrates that the connections between components can be as important, or even more so, than the components themselves, and connections are not present in components, but between them -requiring an increase in scope and hence allowing emergence. It should alert us to the limitations of the state of the art discussed in the introduction, which nearly exclusively focused on the components (e.g. behaviours, sub-behaviours, influences on behaviours, behaviour change principles).

The following story further illustrates the significance of connections in complex social psychological systems: When I learned about how small actions in interconnected systems can cause large cascading domino effects, I developed a particular affinity for helping my friends move. It is a significant life change they are going to go through regardless of your participation, and the potential for unexpected negative consequences of well-meaning actions is minuscule -while you personally are rewarded with free physical activity (pizza and beer are a bonus, too). One common task in such situations is moving a large bed, which typically requires the coordinated effort of two individuals. The key here is not just the presence of two people, but their ability to communicate and work together effectively -blindfolded and in the absence of a coordinating third person, the bed would hardly find its way into the rented van.

In this example, we can see a parallel between the ice, steam, and carbon monoxide scenarios and the bed-moving task: connections between components matter. Changing the individual components (here: replacing the bed-carrying individuals with other people) may not result in noticeable differences, while altering the connections (here: allowing or forbidding communication) can lead to substantial changes in performance. Both research and practical experience demonstrate that a team's performance can be significantly affected by the connections and collaboration between its members. An example from the domain of behaviour change would be the concept of "activity spaces", which aim to change interactions not individuals (Hawe et al., 2009) The potential for interactions to dominate over individuals is essential to understand about interconnectedness, and presents a major divergence from decomposition-based behaviour change thinking. It also brings us to the concept of a network, introduced in Article II.

The concept of networks, as demonstrated in Article II and Figure 2 (B-D), helps us understand interconnectedness, a key feature of complexity outlined in Article III. A network is made up of nodes, usually represented as circles, connected by links, also known as "edges." These links can represent various relationships, such as friendships in social networks or even flight routes between cities. Networked systems are not independent but interconnected.

Interconnectedness can mean not only that people are connected to and affected by other people, but that cognitions and behaviours form systems of feedback, which may impede or enable behaviour change. Such feedback may be accelerating like an arms race pushing the system to new attractors, or balancing such as a thermostat, which carves the current attractor deeper (see Article IV).

At the time of writing, psychological network analysis (Borsboom et al., 2021;Epskamp & Fried, 2018) has become extremely popular. It typically uses links to represent estimates of linear bivariate relationships that remain between two variables, after trying to account for all the other relationships in the network. Article II evaluated the self-reported enactment of behaviour change techniques -such as those in the compendium of techniques for individuals to influence their motivation and behaviour, which was developed in Article I -modelling them as a network where nodes represented techniques, physical activity behaviours, and autonomous and controlled motivation. This network representation directs attention to the holistic pattern of interactions between variables, rather than focusing on how variables are connected to an outcome in isolation.

From Article II's psychological network demonstration, I learned that the best use for such a network might be engaging stakeholders in a needs assessment exercise (Panneer et al., 2021;Reed et al., 2018;Soyster & Fisher, 2019). That is, there was too much uncertainty in assumptions regarding self-report measures and distribution shapes, as well as the assumptions made in linear models (particularly independent and equally distributed data), to draw solid conclusions about the phenomenon at hand. Hence, in Articles III-IV, a recurrence network approach was adopted, where time points are nodes, while links represent repeated occurrences of specific multivariate system states. As the aim of this summary is to give the reader a general-level understanding of complexity in behaviour change, I will omit as peripheral the details of the methodology behind particular empirical demonstrations of complexity concepts made in the articles. I would also like to emphasise that the recurrence network approach is only one example of a complexity-informed analysis technique; a screwdriver, not a toolbox.

Let us return to the topic at hand. We previously discussed how the decomposition-based planning process maps key contexts, people, and behaviours related to larger societal outcomes, identifying influences on behaviours and modulating each influence with the aim of affecting the behaviours -and eventually the overarching problem. But even in the simplistic case of Figure 2C, where four environmental conditions and seven human behaviours are interconnected, there are in total 40 quadrillion 1 causal patterns -different configurations of links -that would need to be evaluated, if we were required to truly understand the problem at hand (see Boisot & McKelvey, 2013, p. 80). Even ruling out 99.99% of these, we still end up with 4 trillion patterns, which may differ between individuals or communities and change over time (see Article III).

Modern science has developed ways to deal with such "epistemological pessimism" -as one prominent behaviour change researcher dubbed it -we will outline those briefly towards the end. But the first step is to admit, that the relationship between macro-level outcome patterns and the behaviours of the micro-level components may not straightforward, and can be sufficiently nuanced so as to be fundamentally out of reach of even the biggest of big data (Bar-Yam, 2016a, 2016b), leading to irreducible uncertainty. I want to emphasise this point, as the success of classical physics made many optimistic that we could eventually learn everything there is to know about behaviours of particular systems. More recently, it has been accepted that in the high-complexity interaction-dominant regimes, there are things that cannot be known for many or any time horizons (Strogatz, 2018). The idea of multiscale emergence is illustrated in Figure 8. Figure 8. A generic model for understanding multiscale problems with human action as a key component -the main interest of behaviour change science. The outcome of interest (black circle; e.g. a society able to dynamically counter pandemic threats) represents an emergent property of a network of smaller scale outcomes (grey circle; e.g. community and organisational scale enablement of precautionary action). Each node of this intermittent scale, in turn, is the emergent property of a network of interwoven smaller scale factors, which enable or constrain positive change.

Note that the network dynamics at the lower scale interact to create the larger scale dynamics, but the larger scale also imposes "downwards causation", constraining the lower scale dynamics (Richardson et al., 2017).

An example of multiscale emergence would be individuals in a hospital, who form a multidisciplinary team of medical experts. The team's performance is different to that of the individuals working in isolation, in part because team membership constrains the individuals actions to an extent -they need to participate in team meetings, for example. This is a simple example of "downwards causation", where higher-scale dynamics constrain the lower scale actions (Richardson et al., 2017). Together with other teams in the hospital, the multidisciplinary team forms a hospital staff, which in part forms a healthcare system, yet another emergent level when scope is expanded.

div.head: PROPERTIES FOR CONSIDERATION IN A COMPLEX SYSTEMS APPROACH TO BEHAVIOUR CHANGE SCIENCE
div.p: Interconnectedness is tied to some properties, namely non-normality, non-linearity, non-stationarity, non-homogeneity, and non-ergodicity, which are seldom discussed in behaviour change. They can be intuitive to practitioners, but largely absent from discussions involving quantitative analysis. I propose to bring them to the forefront when discussing behaviour change, as they enable us to appreciate the richness and diversity of behaviour change processes, as well as the unique challenges and opportunities they present.

div.head: NON-NORMALITY: BEYOND STRAIGHT LINES
div.p: Interconnected systems often defy the assumption of independent and identically distributed data points, which is ubiquitous in behaviour change research. Normal distributions arise universally in systems, which consist of independent components. Interconnectedness can foster non-normality, as interconnected elements are capable of producing outcomes which feed back to each other and thus diverge from the traditional bell curve. The skew can be extreme, such as in the case of pandemics or wars, where a single observation to carry more importance than all the others combined (Cirillo & Taleb, 2016. In survey research, though, the person who would have answered "5000" in the 5-point Likert scale had they had the option, is treated like everyone else who ended up answering "5", and hence not of great gravity. Such observations routinely get discarded as outliers or measurement errors, ignoring Scott E. Page's admonition that for societal change to happen, "all it takes is a few angry people and a lot of positive feedbacks" (Understanding Complexity, 2009). In Article II, practically none of the many distributions inspected resembled a Gaussian, and means were judged to be a poor description of their shape.

Multivariate normality also means that changes abide by smooth Gaussian dynamics with no sudden jumps from one level to the next, as when crossing a tipping point on an attractor landscape to arrive at a radically different state. This has important practical consequences, as "Very much of what seems stable and rigid and reliable eventually wiggles, wobbles and falls down if you watch it long enough" (Kelty-Stephen, 2018, p. 12). This description of effects where the system can radically change its state, brings us to the next property.

div.head: NON-LINEARITY: THE POWER OF (DE-)AMPLIFIED EFFECTS
div.p: Quantitative models in behaviour change research almost exclusively assume that increases in an input should be followed by proportional increases in output. A non-linear effect of an action happens any time, when one unit of increase in the action does not lead to a proportional effect of the action.

Interconnectedness can breed non-linearity, as the relationships between intertwined components may no longer be simply additive or directly proportional. Large changes are not necessarily caused by special eventscrossing an innocuous tipping point can be enough -and long periods of apparent calm can be followed by periods when everything changes at once (think of the last straw breaking the camel's back). Doubling the times you tell the same joke to the same audience, does not double the laughs, and while most times you fall from 10 m you die, falling from 1 m does not make you 1/10th dead (Taleb, 2012;Article III).

In behaviour change, proportional effects should be treated as one case, not the universal one. Note, that non-linearity involves not only the functions not described by a straight line, including what is understood wit the term "non-linear trend", but also "non-linear dynamics", which refer to complex behaviours of interconnected systems, where outputs are not proportional to inputs (Strogatz, 2018). Non-linearity was the norm in long time series of motivation examined in Article III, as was non-stationarity, which we turn to next.

div.head: NON-STATIONARITY: EMBRACING CHANGE AND EVOLUTION
div.p: Non-stationarity, which arises when people develop and change unpredictably over time, is often neglected in behaviour change research that assumes static averages, deviance of which is understood as normally distributed error. We already briefly discussed non-stationarity as a consequence of observing humans as self-organising agents. Non-stationarity appears when people develop and change over time, in ways that are often unpredictable and inconsistent over time frames, hence often not well described by (deviations from static) averages. It can be visualised as an attractor landscape changing its shape, allowing for new states to be accommodated.

The available methods to deal with non-stationary multivariate dynamics in psychology have thus far mostly consisted of Time Varying Auto Regressive (TV-AR; Haslbeck et al., 2020) models, which are limited to linear dynamics and very short time scales -usually only accounting for the effect of a single previous time point. On the other hand, psychological time series have been demonstrated to contain "long-term memory", where values from the distant past influence those of the present, as well as non-stationary autocorrelation functions, where the effect of the past varies in time .

In an open, interconnected system, non-stationarity can be the norm, with the system's dynamics constantly evolving based on the interplay of its elements under adaptation pressures of the environment. The attractor landscape keeps shifting -and with it, the future. Much can be said about implications to traditional randomised controlled designs. Stable, even complicated settings can be much more easily controlled, whereas artificially tight control of complex systems can lead to unwanted consequences, making it necessary to allow for fluctuation and instability (Bar-Yam, 2004b;Taleb & Blyth, 2011). Combined with context-dependence, where the presence or absence of an effect can be determined by the idiographic history of the people partaking an intervention, this presents problems to interventions trying to uncover a general, causal, unbiased, and stable effect size estimate (Greenhalgh et al., 2022;Rickles, 2009) In contrast, the most successful known way of providing the necessary variety to find solutions to evolving challenges, is to counter evolution with evolution (Bar-Yam, 2006); we will return to this point when discussing implications for practice.

div.head: NON-HOMOGENEITY: APPRECIATING THE MOSAIC OF VARIATIONS
div.p: Interconnectedness can lead to non-homogeneity, when there are clusters of components weakly connected to outside the cluster. The characteristics of the system can thus diverge across its different parts (say, communities), potentially making averages over the whole system meaningless. This diversity is invaluable as it produces the variety necessitated by Ashby's law, making the system less vulnerable to abrupt collapse (see Figure 1 in Scheffer et al., 2012;and Figure 8 in Taleb et al., 2014). But, as we saw with scale-dependent complexity, this also means a tradeoff where the system is less able to perform large-scale actions efficiently. The most important implications of non-homogeneity arise when it is combined with non-stationarity, leading to non-ergodicity -which I have mentioned earlier, but finally have the chance to discuss next.

div.head: NON-ERGODICITY: WHEN PATHS DIVERGE
div.p: In the introduction, we briefly discussed how an ergodic system is one where we can draw inferences about the components, not only by studying the components in time, but by comparing the components -which can be assumed to just reside in different points of the same path -to each other (see Article III). In Cattel's data box of Figure 1, comparing horizontal and vertical slices would produce similar results. An ergodic system visits all states equally in the long run, so if individuals were homogeneous and the process stationary (Molenaar, 2008), we would not need the cumbersome process of following individuals in time; we could just take a correlation based on a cross-section of many individuals, and infer that the correlation holds within individuals in time. Given that this is seldom the case, between-individual results from correlations, regression, factor analysis, structural equation modeling or psychological network analysis cannot unproblematically be used to infer within-individual processes (Brandt & Morgan, 2022;Hamaker, 2012Hamaker, , 2023.

The concept of a 'space of possibilities', which describes all states a system can reside in, provides a useful way to understand ergodicity. Consider Figure 9A. Here, each tile represents a potential state. The system's current state is marked by a red dot, and this dot can move freely across the entire grid. Because the dot has an equal chance of landing on any tile, over time, each tile will be visited with the same frequency. Thus, the long-term average state of a single trajectory mirrors the average state of all trajectories at a given point in time. environmental pressures, and visit all tiles equally. B) An attractor appears, which "traps" some trajectories entering its basin of attraction (darker blue). C) The space contains an additional attractor with e.g. an extreme risk (orange tile); trajectories that land there, halt permanently and the system is no longer ergodic, as time averages and ensemble averages diverge. Dashed trajectory remains at risk of being pushed to destruction, despite spending long periods in its characteristic area. D) The space seen from the perspective of the system, as in the policy making context: only the adjacent possible states can be observed. See text for details. Figure exapted from Lewin (1951, p. 92).

In Figure 9B, an attractor -located towards the bottom-right of the starting point -appears. Now, some trajectories will get caught in the attractor's influence; this is still an ergodic situation, as the disproportionate time spent in the attractor by any single trajectory, will be reflected in the number of trajectories in the ensemble at any given time. On the other hand, Figure 9C includes a state from which the system cannot escape once it has been entered (orange tile). Some common examples include bankruptcy and death (Taleb, 2020). Now the system is no longer ergodic; if 50% of the ensemble land on the orange tile and get destroyed, it does not mean that individual trajectories are 50% destroyed -they either are operational or not, and no zombies exist.

An example of the orange-tile scenario would be, where an individual or society encounters a virulent pathogen and fails to respond effectively (Rauch & Bar-Yam, 2006). As long as this state is available, every trajectory will eventually land there and become immobile (Taleb et al., 2014). If this was the human civilisation's space of possibilities, and the civilisation was temporarily trapped in the bottom-right attractor (dashed trajectory), calls to blue-ify the orange tile might be brushed away as wasteful -with eventual, permanent consequences Taleb et al., 2020). Note that the fact that such a jump from one attractor to the next has not happened before, says nothing about its future potential; had it happened, this discussion would not take place. This is a testament to the poverty of past samples in fat-tailed phenomena and non-ergodic environments. Figure 9D presents a scenario that resembles the more realistic situation policy making faces, as the known space of possibilities (tiles 1-6) is limited to "adjacent possible" (Björneborn, 2020) states. The grey tiles (7) represent states that cannot be known until the system moves closer to them. Tiles 1-5 represent adjacent states that allow the system to continue its existence, but the system cannot currently access tiles 4-5 without excessive time or energy cost (red borders indicate barriers to entry). Tile 4 is accessible via tile 3, but the system's ability to reach it might change over time, if and when the space of possibilities changes dynamically over time. In such non-stationary situations, strategies that depend on meticulous, long-term planning can consistently fail: the conditions that plans were based on, are there no longer during their implementation. The detailed 5-year plans of the Soviet Union are a prime example.

I end this section with some more specific ways non-ergodicity affects behaviour change research. First, understanding individual differences and personalising interventions: Non-ergodicity in behaviour change research underscores the importance of considering individual differences and trajectories instead of group-level statistics. This not only influences the understanding of individual responses to interventions, but also suggests that interventions should be specifically tailored to individuals rather than adopting a one-size-fits-all approach. Acknowledgement of non-ergodicity implies more personalised and effective behaviour change interventions that take into account unique patterns and time-varying characteristics of individual behaviour.

Second, there are implications to measurement and interpretation of behaviour change: Due to idiographic variations over time, sparse measurements do not capture true behavioural patterns of individuals in non-ergodic contexts, and the sparseness of within-individual temporal data cannot be replaced by increasing the number of individuals, as is common practice when applying multi-level models (Ram et al., 2017). Therefore, multiple measurements (e.g. > 3) ought to be done based on the the time scale of phenomenon in question (Ram et al., 2017). If, say, four was chosen, and a motivational state was expected to change on a weekly basis, four within-individual measures per week ought to be taken to capture a single state; likewise, a multi-year study of annually shifting global motivation states ought to sample four times per annum. Conversely, a weekly survey would be expected to be informative of monthly state changes.

Furthermore, understanding non-ergodicity helps in more nuanced interpretation of research findings. Even if an intervention shows effectiveness on average, it does not mean it will be effective for each individual, underscoring the need for caution in generalising findings. While this may seem obvious, it is still common practice to aggregate-then-analyse results regarding influences on behaviour, while an analyse-then-aggregate strategy -where individual time series are first analysed separately, then combined with other individuals -would be warranted (Rose et al., 2013). In other words, non-ergodicity implies that mechanisms of interventions ought not to be studied by averaging heterogenous individuals, but by following them in time, making a model of each individual, and only then looking for patterns that repeat across individuals.

div.head: BEYOND EPISTEMOLOGICAL PESSIMISM: ADDRESSING COMPLEX PROBLEMS
div.p: An actor in a complex system controls almost nothing but influences almost everything.

-Scott E. Page (Understanding Complexity, 2009) The introduction of irreducible complexity in cause-and-effect relationships -interaction-dominant dynamics -may seem daunting, if one is bent on discovering only "A causes B"-type of relationships between static entities. In interconnected human systems, these entities -be they e.g. attitudes or people -change, and so do their interrelationships. It can seem daunting if one expects the environmental agents identified during the intervention mapping process, to actually control the environments, as depicted in the Scott E. Page quote above. It can also seem daunting if one is exclusively committed to problem solving approaches, which rely on first decomposing the issue into parts, using analysis only to arrive at solutions to each part, and subsequently implementing the solutions successfully. Some areas of psychology have resolved this conundrum by shifting focus on attractor shifts and the related instability indicators (Olthof, 2023) But luckily, scale-dependent complexity provides some relief to this anxiety: not everything is equally complex, and particularly at the largest scales, there may be less possibilities to mull over.

My proposal is, that behaviour change research ought to consider its object of study as a system of systems, which has states that can be inspected by first fixing a scope. This system, be it a society consisting of communities consisting of people, or a school consisting of classrooms of people likely has properties of complex interconnected systems described in the previous section, and can be evaluated by changing the resolution, starting from the coarsest and including more granular factors to the extent that they affect the coarsest-scale description. This touches base with the conventional behaviour change planning process, where a societal problem is first identified, and then environmental conditions as well as human actions contributing to the problem are included in the consideration -to the extent that they affect the societal problem.

The conventional process continues by mapping "causes of causes" until scales where solutions are implementable, are found. This is generally the level of very granular and tangible behaviours, such as "hospital administrator lists ways to reduce hospital-acquired infections in their context", or "civilians put on respirators when entering a public space". This is also very small scale; if our scope is the society, we need extremely high resolution to observe it. In my proposal, not everything is complex, but phenomena at this scale should particularly be assumed to be so: interacting, with potential of multiple attractor states (see Article IV), non-normally distributed, non-linear, non-stationary, meaningfully differing among individuals, and non-ergodic (see Article III) -unless shown otherwise.

In congruence with Ashby's law, planning for behaviour change on the aforementioned small scale generally needs to be adaptable, experimental and relatively short-term: when temporal scope extends, emergence can wash away a plan's feasibility. Continuous, relatively high-frequency monitoring is required, so that the plans can be adapted when the landscape shifts. It is also the case, that when a situation is non-stationary, past evidence may not be informative of the future, and hence analysis without some form of intervention or change effort is of limited use (Mark & Snowden, 2017). If this scale is determined important for the larger scale issue that is to be solved, here is where we might do well to hand the planning to more "local" autonomous agents, and this is where the compendium of self-enactable techniques to manage one's own motivation and behaviour (Article I) could come in. If community processes -i.e. social support -could be leveraged to further enable people to take up these techniques, they could work as an additional source for variety of responses the system has available (see Figure 3).

div.head: DISTINGUISHING COMPLEX FROM ORDERED REGIMES
div.p: As we have seen, all this does not mean everything in behaviour change is intractably complex. For any given problem, we can, in fact, try to disentangle ordered problem solving regimes from complex ones, in which the environment has a larger variety at its disposal, and hence any system residing in the environment needs to be able to respond accordingly (Boisot & McKelvey, 2013;European Commission: Joint Research Centre et al., 2021;Mark & Snowden, 2017). Facets of problems pertaining to the ordered regime are characterised by slow trends in attractor landscapes, with few large-scale causes that have relatively predictable influences. These would more generally be found in the large-scale part of the complexity profile we visited earlier. In such situations we can focus on uniform, large-scale action, exploiting what we know while monitoring the context, in order to detect regime change rather early than late. For example, a city may have discovered some particularly innovative and fruitful ways to engage its inhabitants in city planning, and once the necessary support structures are in place, the city can continue using these innovations -until environmental changes make them obsolete. In contrast, facets of problems pertaining to the complex regime, could involve aforementioned non-stationary attractor landscapes, volatile dynamics, and intractably many causes and effects. Community engagement practices during the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic are a drastic example.
Some factors distinguishing these two regimes could be formulated as follows:

Predictability: Issues in the ordered regime are more predictable, as they follow known cycles and change slowly. Those in the complex regime are less predictable, due to interaction-dominant dynamics.

Interventions vs. continued systems change: In the ordered regime, conventional episodic interventions may be more sufficient to address the problem, as the system is relatively stable. In complex situations, ongoing incremental systems change may be required to navigate the constantly shifting landscape.

Possibility to be correct vs. need to anticipate: The ordered regime allows for the possibility of being correct with an analytical solution. In the complex regime, the need to anticipate and adapt becomes paramount, as the interconnected issues may unfold in ways that can be described as synergistic, wicked, or intractable. Plans and systems in such environments should be built such that when they eventually fail, they fail in ways that do not cause domino effects -and which can be learned from (Bar-Yam, 2004b;Mark & Snowden, 2017).

Decomposition-based vs. evolutionary solutions: In the ordered regime, decomposition-based solutions may be more effective, as the problem can be reduced to its components, which can be solved in isolation.

However, the complex regime may require evolutionary approaches (Bar-Yam, 2006), as the system adapts and changes in response to interactions among components, the space of possibilities keep evolving, and fatal risks may emerge. What this means is not trying to create solutions, but rather environments that produce solutions -by a dual process of variety creation and selection pressures (Siegenfeld & Bar-Yam, 2020a).

Consider promoting healthier lifestyles in a community, for an example of distinguishing the complex from the ordered. The ordered aspects might be fixing the lack of accessible resources for physical activity, such as public parks and exercise facilities. This would happen on the large-scale/low-resolution part of the complexity profile. The more complex aspects could include the use of such facilities, and therein the influences on people's physical activity habits, such as descriptive and injunctive community norms. Here, a more explorative approach would be needed; capitalising on evolutionary principles to create real-world solutions -"evolutionary engineering" (Bar-Yam, 2006).

The goal of such an evolutionary approach here would be to create an environment, where large amounts of community-led initiatives are produced and selected amongst, through a process of collaborative rivalry. In such an environment, individuals of small teams could compete amongst each other for within-team rewards, while collaborating with the team to compete against other teams for community-level rewards. Communities in a municipality could then compete for municipality-level rewards, while collaborating to compete against other municipalities. This, of course, resembles how many modern organisations -with networked individuals, teams, departments, etc. -are already structured. Note that modern organisations are also a result of adaptation pressures, as increased complexity has slowly made traditional hierarchies unfeasible (Bar-Yam, 2002).

The UK Medical Research Council guidance for complex intervention development suggests an approach of continuous serial iteration, where an intervention is refined according to feedback from repeated testing cycles (Skivington et al., 2021). This may still prove insufficient in highly complex environments. The main difference between evolutionary approaches and current practice is development of diverse parallel solutions in evolutionary engineering: The large variety of these solutions thus provides the system with optionality to pick the most useful ones given a situation, which could not have been anticipated a priori. Capitalising on such an approach may, though, appear inefficient when compared to meticulous planning efforts in the constrained, predictable settings where planning works well. This can lead to difficulties in e.g. convincing funders to pick up the seemingly wasteful approach of parallel evolution. Somehow the notorious failure of the Soviet Union's 5-year planning cycles, does not seem to have dampened our optimism regarding the broad applicability of long-term detailed planning.

div.head: A MORE INCLUSIVE VIEW OF BEHAVIOUR CHANGE UNDER UNCERTAINTY?
div.p: As for the challenges tackled by behaviour change research, I would propose a radically increased emphasis on strategic priorities pointed out by complex systems science. By this, I mean the prevention of sudden large-scale health disasters -"silent risk" -to complement the current focus on more visible but rather slowly creeping issues such as non-communicable diseases. What aids in this endeavour is the realisation that while it is often too difficult to understand a situation comprehensively, it may be much easier to understand what should be done. Consider Figure 9C, where the potential of an attractor shift to destruction ought to be mitigated on a priori grounds, not because there is certainty of its eventual materialisation. At the time of writing, SARS-CoV-2 is allowed to reproduce and mutate relatively freely, even though alternatives are available (Lazarus et al., 2022;Philippe et al., 2023) -this is akin to tolerating a decaying tree next to our house, because costs of felling it are large, and it may not eventually collapse in our direction. Part of the reason for this is the politicisation of pandemic response (Brusselaers et al., 2022), and a route to avoiding the same pitfalls would be to aid in creation of operational capacities for swift action, so that structures which allow low-cost response are available when needed. Fire departments, for example, embody the ability to act fast without becoming tools of, nor risking the popularity of, politicians.

In the absence of dynamically mitigated global connectivity and other precautions (Baker et al., 2023;Lazarus et al., 2022;Siegenfeld & Bar-Yam, 2020b), pandemics continue to threaten to wipe out all public health gains made in the history of humanity Rauch & Bar-Yam, 2006). Protection from such "tail events" -also including climate change -is one side of creating so-called antifragile systems (Taleb, 2012(Taleb, , 2020Taleb & West, 2023), which benefit from disorder instead of being harmed by it. The other side is the exploitation of optionality or "convexity", produced by e.g. the parallel initiatives discussed in evolutionary planning earlier. Consideration of these facets remains a future task for behaviour change research, and is (Heino et al., 2023).

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: In conclusion, I suggest we should complement current practices in behaviour change research with ideas from complex systems science. Most of the issues mentioned here stem from emergence in interconnected systems: just as there is no avalanche in a snowflake, there is no social cohesion in an isolated handshake, no behaviour change in an isolated action, and no pandemic in an isolated infection.

Grappling with non-linear complex systems and multiscale problems often means operating within environments that we can never fully understand or predict in detail. Recognising the complex and ordered regimes in need of different approaches could be a first step to refining our understanding of behaviour change. Accordingly, behaviour change research could benefit from an inclusion of extreme risk mitigation in choosing priorities -in the presence of non-ergodicity, an essential way to increase quality of life is to avoid mass destruction, such as in the case of pandemics, wars, and other "fat tailed" threats (Cirillo & Taleb, 2016Rauch & Bar-Yam, 2006). Evolutionary designs could aid, particularly in early stage intervention planning under complex regimes. And we should stand constantly prepared to adapt, recognising that unforeseen events present both risks and opportunities in the hitherto unknowable future beyond the "adjacent possible" in the space of possibilities.

The smallest scales of a large system contain vast complexity. There, an intervention planner's "micro-management" -contra autonomy support -is likely to lead to errors. In Intervention Mapping (Bartholomew Eldredge et al., 2016) terms, being too specific about individuals' performance objectives is highly detrimental by heterogeneity only when the system in question consists of millions of individuals (remember that non-homogeneity was only one of the complexity features introduced here). If evolutionary designs are not used, the system to be intervened upon must be simplified to the point that the intervention designers understand it; we cannot have millions of performance objectives in the complex regime. So the alternatives are to down-scope problems such that they better fit the Intervention Mapping process, allow for more flexibility (e.g. formulating the performance objective as "person chooses the appropriate action"), or move to evolution-aligned processes, where multiscale solutions emerge from the appropriate structures (Bar-Yam, 2006). This is not to dismiss particular intervention types.; a law that regulates everyone's calorie intake is obviously ludicrous, while laws can also shield individuals from environmental complexity (by upholding e.g. a police force). The point is merely to say that large-scale instruments work sub-optimally when adaptability is required (mostly in the complex regime), and adaptable instruments work sub-optimally when large scale is required (mostly in the ordered regime). Hence, our guiding principle should be to empower people to self-manage the small scale, using the satisfaction of basic psychological needs as a heuristic compass, while shielding them from large-scale complexity they are unable to respond to. This strategy not only promotes adaptability and resilience in the face of complexity but also fosters an environment conducive to self-determination and self-organisation. A major caveat, though, lies in giving too much attention to the small scale, as the system is bound to fail if the larger scales are neglected. Luckily, scale-dependent complexity also implies, that things may turn out to be clearer -less complex -on the largest scales.

But complexity implies that even in larger scales, plans must be able to fail. Martial artists are not taught to never fall, but to fall in such a way that their resilience is not threatened. Whereas intervention research is generally structured such that harm is minimised and learning from failures is maximised, this is often not the case for policy decisions. I hope the current work will also inspire some behaviour change researchers to turn their gaze onto determinants of good governance; how to infuse more science-based complexity thinking in policy makers, the largest scale environmental agents we deal with. Article II: The author took the lead in formulating and revising the initial draft of the manuscript in collaboration with all co-authors, as well as creating the analysis code and the comprehensive online supplement. TV was in charge of planning and analysing physical activity and sedentary behaviour measurements as derived from accelerometer-collected data. RS and EIF imparted their statistical analysis expertise. The trial design and data collection planning, including the chosen measures, were collectively handled by KB, AH, AU, VA-S, TV, RS, and NH. The conception of the study was by NH, in association with the study's co-applicants. As the principal investigator, NH oversaw the research project. The final manuscriptincluding the contributor role disclosure on which this statement is based on -was read and approved by all authors.

Article III: The author crafted the analysis code and the comprehensive online supplement, also being responsible for initial manuscript drafting and its subsequent revisions. The manuscript underwent several rounds of revision for its intellectual depth and content by KK, CN, NH, and FH. The process of empirical data collection saw contributions from the author, KK, and NH. The R package used for the study's analysis was developed and customised by FH, who also lent their expertise to the analytical approach. The final manuscript -including the contributor role disclosure on which this statement is based on -was read and approved by all authors.

Article IV: The author, along with DP, NH, GM, and KR, envisioned and shaped the core idea of the research, also leading the development of the research methodology in collaboration with DP. The author took the responsibility for the project's software, including its validation, and conducted the formal analysis. The author, with DP, led the investigation while also curating the gathered data and managing the resources for the project. The author, in cooperation with NH, drafted the manuscript initially and further participated in its review and editing process alongside DP, NH, GM, and KR. The visualisation of the research findings was done by the author and DP. NH provided supervision throughout the project, and project administration was carried out by the author in association with NH. Lastly, NH and the author were responsible for acquiring the funding for the project. The final manuscript -including the contributor role disclosure on which this statement is based on -was read and approved by all authors.

div.head: SUPPLEMENTARY MATERIALS
div.p: The OSF repository of this work (REF OSF) contains two datasets; one containing approximately 4800 time points of idiographic momentary task based motivation assessments (following protocol described in Hogenelst et al., 2022), and another containing over 300 weekly global work motivation assessments (repeating post-intervention assessment protocol of the aforementioned manuscript). Readers interested in examining features of repeated within-individual time series assessments, are encouraged to explore these datasets.

body.note: To illustrate this concept, consider the following personal example: Before the COVID-19 pandemic, I was an enthusiast of various martial arts disciplines, exploring numerous different approaches rather than mastering a single one in-depth. Over the course of two decades, I transitioned from traditional, more constrained arts to those with fewer assumptions about an opponent's actions. One training session on knife fighting techniques has stuck with me: After losing my weapon and resorting to submission wrestling, my mock-opponent revealed the constrained scope of specialised disciplines compared to the vastness of the space of possibilities: He bit me. I was defeated via momentarily losing my composure due to this surprise. In other words, my environment had an action I had no response to, which caused a subsequent failure to operate successfully.Figure 3Aillustrates, how Ashby's law conceptualises the interplay between challenges and the associated responses.

div.head: DISCLOSURES USE OF LARGE LANGUAGE MODELS (LLM)
div.p: At the time of writing the introduction, LLMs had just appeared on the scene of generative artificial intelligence tools for assisting knowledge work, and the University of Helsinki had endorsed applying them, while requesting a disclosure of use. An LLM -ChatGPT running GPT-4 -was used to assist in some low-complexity tasks of the introduction but not the included papers. Specifically, it was used to flag potentially unclear points in the text and draft initial versions of some paragraphs, based on coarser input from the author. It was also used to create lists of real-world examples of the concepts introduced, from which some ended up being further developed and eventually used, as well as assisting in producing the following article contribution report from the contributor role statements of the articles.

div.head: CONTRIBUTION TO THE ARTICLES
div.p: The author's contributions to the articles included are as follows; please see original publications (Heino et al., 2019(Heino et al., , 2022Heino, Knittle, et al., 2021;Knittle et al., 2020) for the full author lists. . More specifically, they initially worked closely with MB, NH, KK, and MS to agree on mapping techniques from different sources and refine their definitions. In instances where some techniques proved limited in their self-enactability, the author, together with KK, decided on their removal. Contributing to the creation of instructive examples for each technique was another task the author undertook, collaborating with e.g. FE, NH, KK, and MMM.
